title: USS Locust (AN-22)
text:
USS "Locust" (YN-17/AN-22) was an built for the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. She was later transferred to the <a href="French%20Navy">French Navy</a> as "Locuste" (A765).
She was sold to Malaysian owners but sank after striking a reef off Cikobia Island, <a href="Fiji">Fiji</a>, on 30 July 1978. She was towing the former French ship , which also sank.
Career.
The second ship to be so named by the Navy, "Locust" (YN-17) was laid down by the <a href="American%20Shipbuilding%20Company">American Shipbuilding Company</a>, <a href="Cleveland%2C%20Ohio">Cleveland, Ohio</a>, 18 October 1940; launched 1 February 1941; and placed in service 13 July 1941 for passage down the <a href="St.%20Lawrence%20River">St. Lawrence River</a> for a year of net-laying duties in the <a href="3d%20Naval%20District">3d Naval District</a> off <a href="New%20York%2C%20New%20York">New York, New York</a>, before commissioning December, 1942, LT R. Jordan, <a href="USNR">USNR</a>, in command.
Assigned to the <a href="Service%20Squadron%2C%20Pacific%20Fleet">Service Squadron, Pacific Fleet</a>, the beginning of 1943, "Locust" laid and tended <a href="torpedo%20net">torpedo net</a>s, moorings, and <a href="buoy">buoy</a>s and participated in various towing and salvage operations in the South <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> through World War II.
The net tender was off San Cristobel Island, in the <a href="Solomon%20Islands">Solomon Islands</a>, in April 1943 with <a href="Task%20Unit">Task Unit</a> 32.4.7 when she came under attack the 5th. For about 5 minutes "Locust", with "YAG-26" in tow, was not only dodging fire from a <a href="Empire%20of%20Japan">Japanese</a> bomber but also a <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> from an undetected enemy <a href="submarine">submarine</a>.
Successfully evading the assault, she continued her small but vital role in the ultimate naval victory, serving in the Solomon Islands, <a href="Marshall%20Islands">Marshall Islands</a>, and <a href="New%20Hebrides">New Hebrides</a> through her reclassification to "AN-22" on 20 January 1944.
She departed for the <a href="U.S.%20West%20Coast">U.S. West Coast</a> 6 August 1945, arriving <a href="San%20Pedro%2C%20California">San Pedro, California</a>, the 18th. With the postwar disarmament policy in force "Locust" spent the next 6 months moving from one west coast berthing area to another until 8 July 1946 when she decommissioned at <a href="Astoria%2C%20Oregon">Astoria, Oregon</a>, and entered the <a href="Atlantic%20Reserve%20Fleet">Atlantic Reserve Fleet</a> in the <a href="Columbia%20River">Columbia River</a>, <a href="Oregon">Oregon</a>, where she remained until stricken from the <a href="U.S.%20Naval%20Vessel%20Register">U.S. Naval Vessel Register</a> 1 September 1962.
"Locust" was later sold to and commissioned in the <a href="French%20Navy">French Navy</a> as "Locuste" (A765). In later service, she struck a reef off Cikobia Island, <a href="Fiji">Fiji</a>, 30 July 1978 and sank.
